awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance the understanding of cosmic rays, enigmatic particles from space that continuously bombard our planet. Cosmic rays carry valuable information about the nature of the universe, and unlocking their secrets is crucial for understanding their origin and journey from their sources to Earth. The project aims to analyze nearly a decade of data collected by the High Altitude Water Cherenkov (HAWC) Observatory in Mexico to create detailed maps of the cosmic ray arrival direction distribution. By studying cosmic ray anisotropy and integrating it with their energy spectrum and mass composition, the project can uncover insights into their propagation across the Milky Way and pinpoint the potential existence of a nearby source. This knowledge is also crucial for unraveling the properties of astrophysical plasmas in the interstellar medium, including the very local environment, such as the heliosphere. Through outreach efforts, including engagement with underrepresented communities and the development of educational programs, the project will inspire the next generation of scientists and foster a diverse and inclusive scientific community. 

The research analyzes cosmic ray data collected by the HAWC Observatory to study cosmic ray anisotropy. Cosmic rays, high-energy particles originating from distant unresolved sources, pose numerous challenges in their study due to the poorly understood acceleration mechanisms and interactions with magnetic fields while propagating in space. The analysis aims to produce high-resolution sky maps of cosmic ray arrival direction distribution across a wide energy range (1-100 TeV) and investigate its temporal stability, energy spectral features, and angular structure. Combining data from HAWC and IceCube will provide all-sky maps of cosmic ray anisotropy from 10 TeV to 100 TeV, enabling unprecedented insights into their origins and propagation mechanisms. The research will contribute to advancements in understanding the properties of interstellar magnetized plasma turbulence. This knowledge will help uncover the mechanisms behind cosmic ray acceleration and propagation, shedding light on the nature of their galactic sources and the structure of the interstellar medium. Furthermore, the study of cosmic ray anisotropy has practical implications, such as space weather forecasting and radiation protection for astronauts. The project takes advantage of the large data volume available to develop analyses and investigate the origin of the observation, promoting the education and outreach goals by exposing students to scientific research and educating the next generation of scientists. In addition, the published results will be relevant to study the heliosphere's effects on TeV cosmic rays reaching Earth from space.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes: Cosmic-Ray Anisotropy Analysis


The primary goal of this project was to conduct a comprehensive analysis of the distribution of cosmic-ray arrival directions in the northern hemisphere, for energy ranges between approximately 1 TeV and 100 TeV. This analysis utilized data from the HAWC (High-Altitude Water Cherenkov) observatory, drawing on 250 billion cosmic-ray showers collected from 2015 to 2023. Our findings not only enhance our understanding of cosmic-ray propagation but also have broader implications for cosmic-ray research.


Intellectual Merit


The project's intellectual merit stems from significant improvements in the analysis of cosmic-ray anisotropy. The research team overhauled the analysis procedure, incorporating advancements in event quality selection, pressure correction methods, and an in-depth investigation into how cosmic-ray particle energy is distributed across the field of view. This was achieved by utilizing updated Monte Carlo simulations and correcting for the orbital Compton-Getting effect, which can create distortions in measurements if left unaddressed. These refinements ensure more accurate and reliable measurements, making this the most detailed analysis of cosmic-ray anisotropy to date.


Moreover, combining data from HAWC and the IceCube observatory enabled us to produce full-sky maps of cosmic-ray anisotropy, overcoming the limitations posed by incomplete sky coverage in individual experiments. The new maps, covering energy ranges from approximately 10 TeV to 100 TeV, offer a clearer picture of the cosmic-ray distribution in both hemispheres, which is essential for understanding large-scale structures such as the dipole anisotropy, believed to be associated with diffusive propagation of cosmic-ray particles in the interstellar medium.


Broader Impacts


This project not only advanced scientific understanding but also contributed to the training of future scientists. Two undergraduate students and one Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) student were directly involved in the data analysis and methodological development. Their participation provided valuable hands-on experience in cutting-edge cosmic-ray astrophysics and exposure to the broader scientific process through collaborations and presentations at group meetings and symposia.


The development of state-of-the-art cosmic-ray anisotropy sky maps and their public release fosters interdisciplinary collaboration. These maps serve as vital experimental data for scientists studying cosmic-ray propagation in the interstellar medium and the heliosphere. The findings also have broader implications for understanding the local interstellar magnetic field and its influence on cosmic rays. Making these maps publicly available encourages further research and exploration across multiple scientific disciplines.


Key Accomplishments


1. Data Collection and Processing: The analysis involved a dataset four times larger than previous studies, with improved event quality and stability through advanced pressure and orbital Compton-Getting Effect correction techniques. This improved temporal stability ensures a more accurate depiction of cosmic-ray anisotropy.

   

2. Cosmic-Ray Anisotropy Mapping: We produced the most detailed relative intensity sky maps of cosmic-ray arrival directions in the energy range of 1 TeV to 100 TeV using HAWC data. Additionally, combining HAWC and IceCube data yielded full-sky maps of cosmic-ray anisotropy from 10 TeV to 100 TeV, offering the only full-sky measurement to date.


3. Joint Analysis with IceCube: Combining HAWC and IceCube data allowed for a more comprehensive analysis of cosmic-ray anisotropy across the entire sky. This collaboration overcame the biases introduced by experiments with limited fields of view, providing a new tool to extend our understanding of large-scale structures in cosmic-ray arrival directions and cosmic-ray propagation in the interstellar medium.


4. Training and Professional Development: Undergraduate students and an REU student gained valuable research experience in data analysis and astrophysics, contributing directly to the project's success. Their involvement exemplifies how research projects can serve as educational growth and skill development platforms.


5. Dissemination and Impact: Preliminary results were presented at the SuGAR 2024 symposium in October 2024, and the final analyses are being completed and will be published in scientific journals. The release of full-sky anisotropy maps in a publicly accessible format will facilitate further studies by researchers worldwide, ensuring that the project's findings benefit the broader scientific community.


Conclusion


The outcomes of this project mark significant progress in cosmic-ray research, offering the most detailed and comprehensive analysis of cosmic-ray anisotropy in the northern hemisphere to date. By combining data from multiple observatories, addressing methodological limitations, and involving students in the research process, this project advances scientific knowledge and fosters the next generation of researchers. The public release of data and sky maps will be a valuable resource for the global scientific community, enabling continued exploration and discovery in cosmic-ray astrophysics.
